claim.text: Softwood has a thermal resistance of approximately R-1.25 per inch, while the batt insulation provides R-3.5 per inch
claim.claim: Softwood has thermal resistance of approximately R-1.25 per inch; fiberglass batt insulation provides R-3.5 per inch

results.summary: Both R-values cited are accurate and consistent with established building science standards.
results.detail: Softwood lumber (such as pine, spruce, fir) has a well-documented thermal resistance of approximately R-1.0 to R-1.25 per inch, with R-1.25 being a commonly cited value. Fiberglass batt insulation typically provides R-3.0 to R-3.8 per inch depending on density, with R-3.5 per inch being a standard value for medium-density batts. These figures are consistent with values published by the U.S. Department of Energy, ASHRAE, and building code references.
sources: U.S. Department of Energy Energy Saver insulation guidance
ASHRAE Handbook of Fundamentals
Building Science Corporation technical resources

claim.text: The studs conduct heat at nearly three times the rate of the insulation they interrupt
claim.claim: Wood studs conduct heat at nearly three times the rate of fiberglass batt insulation

results.summary: The claim that wood studs conduct heat at nearly three times the rate of fiberglass batt insulation is accurate based on established thermal conductivity values.
results.detail: Softwood framing lumber (pine, spruce, fir) has a thermal conductivity of approximately 0.12-0.15 W/(m·K), while fiberglass batt insulation has a thermal conductivity of approximately 0.035-0.045 W/(m·K). The ratio is approximately 3:1, matching the claim. This is well-documented in building science literature and is the primary cause of thermal bridging in wood-framed construction. The R-value comparison (R-1.0-1.25/inch for wood vs R-3.0-3.8/inch for fiberglass) confirms the same relationship.
sources: ASHRAE Handbook - Fundamentals (thermal properties of building materials)
DOE Building America program thermal bridging research
Building Science Corporation technical resources

claim.text: When engineers calculate effective R-value rather than nominal R-value, that R-22 wall performs closer to R-15
claim.claim: A nominal R-22 wood-framed wall with 25% framing factor has an effective R-value closer to R-15

results.summary: The claim aligns with well-established building science calculations for thermal bridging in wood-framed walls.
results.detail: The phenomenon described is the thermal bridging effect, where wood studs (approximately R-1.25 per inch) conduct heat more readily than insulation, reducing whole-wall R-value. With 25% framing factor and R-22 cavity insulation in a 2x6 wall, parallel path heat flow calculations typically yield effective R-values in the R-14 to R-16 range, making R-15 a reasonable approximation. This calculation method is documented in ASHRAE Handbook of Fundamentals and used in energy codes. The exact result depends on framing depth and whether interior/exterior sheathing R-values are included.
sources: ASHRAE Handbook of Fundamentals - thermal bridging calculations
Building Science Corporation technical resources on whole-wall R-value
ORNL whole-wall R-value calculator methodology
